newsitem.title: INDIA: CRICKET-PAKISTAN WORRIED ABOUT EASING UP IN FINAL.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-PAKISTAN WORRIED ABOUT EASING UP IN FINAL.

text.p: Pakistan captain Rameez Raja is worried his team may ease up in the Independence Cup final against Sri Lanka after their victory-to-savour over arch-rivals India.
"That's what we don't want," Raja said on Friday in Mohali, where Pakistan play the World Cup champions on Saturday in the first match of a best-of-three final at the limited overs tournament.
Pakistan were elated after beating India in Madras on Wednesday in the league stage.

"Winning against India meant a lot to us after the fury we faced when we went back home," Raja said in a reference to events after Pakistan's quarter-final defeat by India at Bangalore in last year's World Cup.
"We can safely go back home now," he said.
Raja said the final would in all probability be a high-scoring affair on the easy-paced Mohali pitch.

Pakistan opener Saeed Anwar, who flayed India in Madras with 194, the highest individual score in a one-day international, said the Mohali game could well be a face-off between Sri Lankan opener Sanath Jayasuriya and Pakistan's Shahid Afridi.
Both have a reputation for thunderous batting in the early overs, but Raja played down Afridi's role.

"He is a young Pathan with a lot of talent, with an extremely good temperament. But we have to keep him under control. You know how a Pathan is," Raja said of Afridi, in an apparent reference to martial Pathans' reputation for impetuousness.
Pakistan are to play Sri Lanka in Calcutta next Tuesday in the second match of the final, with a third game on Wednesday in Calcutta if the teams are level 1-1.
India and New Zealand bowed out at the end of the league stage of the tournament commemorating the 50th anniversary of India's independence from Britain.
